author: @echnaton4989
text: I agree with sentdex on the part of starting programing. I first was introduced to C++ and I had a really though time understanding how to write code, because it's that close to the machine. Now I'm learning Python and it's way easier and I now understand alot of things in C++, which were just to complicated without basic knowledge of coding. So beginners I would recommend to start with python and then maybe take a look at C++.

author: @__Beant__
text: Sorry if you already thought about this, but what about training a neural network to detect the puck in varying lighting conditions? You could use the frame as input and the centre of the circle as output for building the training set. Then tune your threshold values manually for some different lighting situations like white daylight and yellow lamp light, low light etc. It would be interesting to see if a NN could generalise to new mixed lighting scenarios.

author: @TheNiters
text: You need a special case if the puck location is past the arm, that just moves the arm along the back edge from the middle so it can push the puck out onto the board again :)

author: @Lambda_Ovine
text: Can you mathematically define a line between where the puck gets stuck in a corner and where the arm can hit it, and then establish that if the puck stays in the said of that line where the arm can't hit it (gets stuck in the corner) for more than, let's say, 2 seconds, the arm will then lift the 'whatever-its-holding' and position where the puck is, then push down, and with a quick move forward it will throw the puck back to the 'field'.
